prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a frequency set-up allowing us to cover the CO(2-1) line with a 1875 MHz baseband (1631 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz (~1.27 km/s). This covers the entire velocity width expected, including any high-velocity gas detected around the SMBH. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. We retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions, to reach an optimal compromise between spectral resolution and S/N (and minimise the uncertainty on the derived SMBH mass).
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies, to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

NGC1574 has an estimated SMBH mass M_BH~2.4x10^8 M_sun, and a SMBH sphere of influence of ~0.26", given the known distance to this object (and its velocity dispersion from van den Bosch et al., 2015). Davis 2014 discuss in detail the resolution required to estimate SMBH masses using this technique, when defining their figure of merit. Using this formalism, in principle one could measure the SMBH mass in this object out to ~0.5". However, as shown in Figure 1 & 3, well resolving the SMBH sphere of influence significantly increases the accuracy of the SMBH mass measurement. Especially in view of the unknown variation of SMBH mass across the mass-size plane, we also plan conservatively, allowing ourselves to place strong upper limits (up to a dex below the M-sigma relation) if the SMBH is smaller than expected. In order to be sensitive to an SMBH of this size, we propose to obtain two beams inside the SOI; a resolution of 0.15 arcseconds. This will be more than enough to clearly separate the SMBH kinematic signature from that of the bulk of the stars given a good velocity resolution and signal-to-noise ratio (see Fig. 3).
We propose to map NGC1574 in the CO(2-1) line (Band 6), for which the flux is known. One can reach the required resolution in this band using array configuration C36-5. The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is ~2.1, marginally smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk (see Fig. 2), but much larger than the region we must image near the SMBH (Figs. 3-4). Our past work has established the importance of low spatial resolution molecular gas observations and associated mass modelling to anchor the dynamical models on larger (intermediate) spatial scales (arcsecond scales; 100s of parsecs; see Fig. 1; e.g. Young et al. 2008; Davis et al. 2013a, b). We thus request short observations of each of these targets using the 12m array at lower spatial resolution to the same surface brightness limit. In addition to tightening constraints on the SMBH mass, this will ensure we do not resolve out substantial amounts of flux, even if the disk is smooth and does not break into individual GMCs.
To show that the requested configuration will fulfil our science goals, we created mock observations using our simulation tools (Davis et al. 2013a, b), the total circular velocity curve estimated from mass modelling of the stellar light distribution, and assuming the CO is distributed in an exponential disk with a size matching the dust seen in Fig.3. These were then input into the CASA ALMA simulator, and the results are shown in the right panel of Figure 3. We do not resolve out flux, the uv coverage and image quality are excellent, and most importantly the kinematic signature of the SMBH is clearly detected, demonstrating that our proposed observations and analysis methods are sound.

This galaxy has CO(2-1) single-dish observations from Davis et al., in prep (see spectrum in Figure 3). From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (see Table 1). We estimate the size of the molecular gas reservoir using HST observations which reveal a dust disk in the centre of this object. Experience shows that the emission is normally only spatially resolved in one direction (tracing the ``spider'' diagram) in individual velocity channels. We thus take the number of synthesised beams across the source in each channel as the ratio of the minor-axis length (~2.4; see Fig. 2) to the synthesised beam size (0.13"; justified below). We assume the observed flux per channel is split between these beams, giving us the expected surface brightness per beam we need to reach in these observations. Requiring a detection of this emission at a signal to noise of 3 leads to the requested RMS listed in Table 1.
The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

We request a frequency set-up allowing us to cover the CO(2-1) line with a 1875 MHz baseband (1631 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz (~1.27 km/s). This covers the entire velocity width expected, including any high-velocity gas detected around the SMBH. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. We retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions, to reach an optimal compromise between spectral resolution and S/N (and minimise the uncertainty on the derived SMBH mass).
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies, to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

NGC2110 has an estimated SMBH mass M_BH~4.1x10^8 M_sun, and a SMBH sphere of influence of ~0.26", given the known distance to this object (and its velocity dispersion from van den Bosch et al., 2015). Davis 2014 discuss in detail the resolution required to estimate SMBH masses using this technique, when defining their figure of merit. Using this formalism, in principle one could measure the SMBH mass in this object out to ~0.34". However, as shown in Figure 1 & 3, well resolving the SMBH sphere of influence significantly increases the accuracy of the SMBH mass measurement. Especially in view of the unknown variation of SMBH mass across the mass-size plane, we also plan conservatively, allowing ourselves to place strong upper limits (up to a dex below the M-sigma relation) if the SMBH is smaller than expected. In order to be sensitive to an SMBH of this size, we propose to obtain two beams inside the SOI; a resolution of 0.13 arcseconds. This will be more than enough to clearly separate the SMBH kinematic signature from that of the bulk of the stars given a good velocity resolution and signal-to-noise ratio (see Fig. 3).
We propose to map NGC2110 in the CO(2-1) line (Band 6), for which the flux is known. One can reach the required resolution in this band using array configuration C36-5. The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk (see Fig. 2), but much larger than the region we must image near the SMBH (Figs. 3-4). Our past work has established the importance of low spatial resolution molecular gas observations and associated mass modelling to anchor the dynamical models on larger (intermediate) spatial scales (arcsecond scales; 100s of parsecs; see Fig. 1; e.g. Young et al. 2008; Davis et al. 2013a, b). We thus request a short observation of each of this target using the 12m array at lower spatial resolution to the same surface brightness limit. In addition to tightening constraints on the SMBH mass, this will ensure we do not resolve out substantial amounts of flux, even if the disk is smooth and does not break into individual GMCs.
To show that the requested configuration will fulfil our science goals, we created mock observations using our simulation tools (Davis et al. 2013a, b), the total circular velocity curve estimated from mass modelling of the stellar light distribution, and assuming the CO is distributed in an exponential disk with a size matching the dust seen in Fig.3. These were then input into the CASA ALMA simulator, and the results are shown in the right panel of Figure 3. We do not resolve out flux, the uv coverage and image quality are excellent, and most importantly the kinematic signature of the SMBH is clearly detected, demonstrating that our proposed observations and analysis methods are sound.

This galaxy has CO(2-1) single-dish observations from Davis et al., in prep (see spectrum in Figure 3). From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (see Table 1). We estimate the size of the molecular gas reservoir using HST observations which reveal dusty spiral arms and disk structure in the centre of this object. Experience shows that the emission is normally only spatially resolved in one direction (tracing the ``spider'' diagram) in individual velocity channels. We thus take the number of synthesised beams across the source in each channel as the ratio of the minor-axis length (~3.5"; see Fig. 2) to the synthesised beam size (0.13"; justified below). We assume the observed flux per channel is split between these beams, giving us the expected surface brightness per beam we need to reach in these observations. Requiring a detection of this emission at a signal to noise of 3 leads to the requested RMS listed in Table 1.
The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

We request a frequency set-up allowing us to cover the CO(2-1) line with a 1875 MHz baseband (1631 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz (~1.27 km/s). This covers the entire velocity width expected, including any high-velocity gas detected around the SMBH. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. W We retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions, to reach an optimal compromise between spectral resolution and S/N (and minimise the uncertainty on the derived SMBH mass).
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies, to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

NGC0383 has an estimated SMBH mass M_BH~1x10^9 M_sun, and a SMBH sphere of influence of ~0.2", given the known distance to this object (and its velocity dispersion from van den Bosch et al., 2015). Davis 2014 discuss in detail the resolution required to estimate SMBH masses using this technique, when defining their figure of merit. Using this formalism, in principle one could measure the SMBH mass in this object out to ~0.38". However, as shown in Figure 1 & 3, well resolving the SMBH sphere of influence significantly increases the accuracy of the SMBH mass measurement. Especially in view of the unknown variation of SMBH mass across the mass-size plane, we also plan conservatively, allowing ourselves to place strong upper limits (up to a dex below the M-sigma relation) if the SMBH is smaller than expected. In order to be sensitive to an SMBH of this size, we propose to obtain two beams inside the SOI; a resolution of 0.1 arcseconds. This will be more than enough to clearly separate the SMBH kinematic signature from that of the bulk of the stars given a good velocity resolution and signal-to-noise ratio (see Fig. 3).
We propose to map NGC0383 in the CO(2-1) line (Band 6), for which the flux is known. One can reach the required resolution in this band using array configuration C34-6. The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk (see Fig. 2), but much larger than the region we must image near the SMBH (Figs. 3-4). Our past work has established the importance of low spatial resolution molecular gas observations and associated mass modelling to anchor the dynamical models on larger (intermediate) spatial scales (arcsecond scales; 100s of parsecs; see Fig. 1; e.g. Young et al. 2008; Davis et al. 2013a, b). We thus request a short observation of each of this target using the 12m array at lower spatial resolution to the same surface brightness limit (see science goal NGC0383-lowres). In addition to tightening constraints on the SMBH mass, this will ensure we do not resolve out substantial amounts of flux, even if the disk is smooth and does not break into individual GMCs. We do not expect to loose flux or be affected by imaging artefacts, as the resolution requested is a the low end of that provided for the C36-6 array, and thus the baseline overlap between the configurations is sufficient.
To show that the requested configuration will fulfil our science goals, we created mock observations using our simulation tools (Davis et al. 2013a, b), the total circular velocity curve estimated from mass modelling of the stellar light distribution, and assuming the CO is distributed in an exponential disk with a size matching the dust seen in Fig.3. These were then input into the CASA ALMA simulator, and the results are shown in the right panel of Figure 3. We do not resolve out flux, the uv coverage and image quality are excellent, and most importantly the kinematic signature of the SMBH is clearly detected, demonstrating that our proposed observations and analysis methods are sound.

This galaxy has CO(2-1) single-dish observations from Davis et al., in prep (see spectrum in Figure 3). From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (see Table 1). We estimate the size of the molecular gas reservoir using HST observations which reveal dusty spiral arms and disk structure in the centre of this object. Experience shows that the emission is normally only spatially resolved in one direction (tracing the ``spider'' diagram) in individual velocity channels. We thus take the number of synthesised beams across the source in each channel as the ratio of the minor-axis length (~5.0"; see Fig. 2) to the synthesised beam size (0.1"; justified below). We assume the observed flux per channel is split between these beams, giving us the expected surface brightness per beam we need to reach in these observations. Requiring a detection of this emission at a signal to noise of 3 leads to the requested RMS listed in Table 1.
The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

We request an identical frequency set-up to our higher resolution track, to allow the data to be combined. We will cover the CO(2-1) line with a 1875 MHz baseband (1631 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz (~1.27 km/s). This covers the entire velocity width expected, including any high-velocity gas detected around the SMBH. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. We retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions, to reach an optimal compromise between spectral resolution and S/N (and minimise the uncertainty on the derived SMBH mass).
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies, to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

The largest angular scale visible in the CS36-6 array configuration is smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk in this object (see Fig. 3), but much larger than the region we must image near the SMBH (Figs. 3-4). Our past work has established the importance of low spatial resolution molecular gas observations and associated mass modelling to anchor the dynamical models on larger (intermediate) spatial scales (arcsecond scales; 100s of parsecs; see Fig. 1; e.g. Young et al. 2008; Davis et al. 2013a, b). We thus here request a short observation of this target using the 12m array at lower spatial resolution (C36-3) to reach the same surface brightness limit. In addition to tightening constraints on the SMBH mass, this will ensure we do not resolve out substantial amounts of flux, even if the disk is smooth and does not break into individual GMCs. We here select a beam size of 0.5", which will ensure baseline overlap with the higher resolution track while still recovering emission over the LAS of the source.

In the science goal we aim to provide an intermediate resolution image of NGC0449 which can be combined with the higher resolution track, as discussed in the imaging section. We thus match the surface brightness sensitivity of that track, but with a larger beam calibrated to ensure the LAS of the source is recovered. We keep the same correlator setup and channel sizes, to ensure the tracks can be efficiently combined.

We request a frequency set-up allowing us to cover the CO(2-1) line with a 1875 MHz baseband (1631 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz (~1.27 km/s). This covers the entire velocity width expected, including any high-velocity gas detected around the SMBH. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. We retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions, to reach an optimal compromise between spectral resolution and S/N (and minimise the uncertainty on the derived SMBH mass).
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies, to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

NGC0449 has an estimated SMBH mass M_BH~5x10^8 M_sun, and a SMBH sphere of influence of ~0.2", given the known distance to this object (and its velocity dispersion from van den Bosch et al., 2015). Davis 2014 discuss in detail the resolution required to estimate SMBH masses using this technique, when defining their figure of merit. Using this formalism, in principle one could measure the SMBH mass in this object out to ~0.39". However, as shown in Figure 1 & 3, well resolving the SMBH sphere of influence significantly increases the accuracy of the SMBH mass measurement. Especially in view of the unknown variation of SMBH mass across the mass-size plane, we also plan conservatively, allowing ourselves to place strong upper limits (up to a dex below the M-sigma relation) if the SMBH is smaller than expected. In order to be sensitive to an SMBH of this size, we propose to obtain two beams inside the SOI; a resolution of 0.1 arcseconds. This will be more than enough to clearly separate the SMBH kinematic signature from that of the bulk of the stars given a good velocity resolution and signal-to-noise ratio (see Fig. 3).
We propose to map NGC0449 in the CO(2-1) line (Band 6), for which the flux is known. One can reach the required resolution in this band using array configuration C34-6. The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk (see Fig. 2), but much larger than the region we must image near the SMBH (Figs. 3-4). Our past work has established the importance of low spatial resolution molecular gas observations and associated mass modelling to anchor the dynamical models on larger (intermediate) spatial scales (arcsecond scales; 100s of parsecs; see Fig. 1; e.g. Young et al. 2008; Davis et al. 2013a, b). We thus request a short observation of each of this target using the 12m array at lower spatial resolution to the same surface brightness limit (see science goal NGC0449-lowres). In addition to tightening constraints on the SMBH mass, this will ensure we do not resolve out substantial amounts of flux, even if the disk is smooth and does not break into individual GMCs. We do not expect to loose flux or be affected by imaging artefacts, as the resolution requested is a the low end of that provided for the C36-6 array, and thus the baseline overlap between the configurations is sufficient.
To show that the requested configuration will fulfil our science goals, we created mock observations using our simulation tools (Davis et al. 2013a, b), the total circular velocity curve estimated from mass modelling of the stellar light distribution, and assuming the CO is distributed in an exponential disk with a size matching the dust seen in Fig.3. These were then input into the CASA ALMA simulator, and the results are shown in the right panel of Figure 3. We do not resolve out flux, the uv coverage and image quality are excellent, and most importantly the kinematic signature of the SMBH is clearly detected, demonstrating that our proposed observations and analysis methods are sound.

This galaxy has CO(2-1) single-dish observations from Davis et al., in prep (see spectrum in Figure 3). From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (see Table 1). We estimate the size of the molecular gas reservoir using HST observations which reveal dusty spiral arms and disk structure in the centre of this object. Experience shows that the emission is normally only spatially resolved in one direction (tracing the ``spider'' diagram) in individual velocity channels. We thus take the number of synthesised beams across the source in each channel as the ratio of the minor-axis length (~4.9"; see Fig. 2) to the synthesised beam size (0.1"; justified below). We assume the observed flux per channel is split between these beams, giving us the expected surface brightness per beam we need to reach in these observations. Requiring a detection of this emission at a signal to noise of 3 leads to the requested RMS listed in Table 1.
The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

We request an identical frequency set-up to our higher resolution track, to allow the data to be combined. We will cover the CO(2-1) line with a 1875 MHz baseband (1631 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976 MHz (~1.27 km/s). This covers the entire velocity width expected, including any high-velocity gas detected around the SMBH. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. Davis 2014 analysed this dependance, and suggest an ideal channel width of 20 km/s, which minimises SMBH mass errors while still allowing reasonable integration times. We retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions, to reach an optimal compromise between spectral resolution and S/N (and minimise the uncertainty on the derived SMBH mass).
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies, to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

The largest angular scale visible in the CS36-6 array configuration is smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk in this object (see Fig. 3), but much larger than the region we must image near the SMBH (Figs. 3-4). Our past work has established the importance of low spatial resolution molecular gas observations and associated mass modelling to anchor the dynamical models on larger (intermediate) spatial scales (arcsecond scales; 100s of parsecs; see Fig. 1; e.g. Young et al. 2008; Davis et al. 2013a, b). We thus here request a short observation of this target using the 12m array at lower spatial resolution (C36-3) to reach the same surface brightness limit. In addition to tightening constraints on the SMBH mass, this will ensure we do not resolve out substantial amounts of flux, even if the disk is smooth and does not break into individual GMCs. We here select a beam size of 0.5", which will ensure baseline overlap with the higher resolution track while still recovering emission over the LAS of the source.

In the science goal we aim to provide an intermediate resolution image of NGC0383 which can be combined with the higher resolution track, as discussed in the imaging section. We thus match the surface brightness sensitivity, of that track, but with a larger beam calibrated to ensure the LAS of the source is recovered. We keep the same correlator setup and channel sizes, to ensure the tracks can be efficiently combined.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Ubiquitously present at the centres of galaxies, black holes are central to understanding galaxy evolution. However, the current sample of galaxies with measured black-hole masses is incredibly biased, tracing only specific regions of the mass-size and mass-velocity dispersion planes. As many galaxy properties vary across these planes, this bias could be fundamentally affecting our understanding of black hole scaling relations, and thus the relationship between galaxies and their SMBHs. As part of the mm-Wave Interferometric Survey of Dark Object Masses (WISDOM) we have pioneered the use of molecular gas to estimate SMBH masses, and conducted the preparatory work required to select a large sample of suitable ALMA target objects. We here propose to map CO(2-1) at high resolution, in a sample of objects which span the unexplored areas of the mass-size plane, accurately measuring their SMBH mass. In this way we can address this bias, extending SMBH demographics, and shed light for the first time on potential variations of SMBH-galaxy correlations using the same technique (with the same systematics) across the galaxy mass-size plane.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, Astronomy and Mathematics, Hertfordshire, University of
